COVID-19 infection not linked to changes in MS symptom severity - Medical Xpress
summary:
COVID-19 infection not linked to changes in MS symptom severity

Publication Date: December 23, 2024 Source: Neurology

COVID-19 infection is not associated with immediate changes in multiple sclerosis (MS) symptom severity or disability, according to a study published online.

  • The study examined 796 participants with COVID-19 infections and 1,336 uninfected individuals.
  • Findings indicated that MS symptoms and disability did not significantly differ between cohorts.
  • The immediate effect of COVID-19 on MS symptom severity was minimal.
"These findings enhance our general understanding of the consequences of infection in people with MS and are reassuring regarding the impact of COVID-19 on the course of MS," the authors write.

In conclusion, the study reassures that COVID-19 does not significantly impact the symptoms or disability of patients with multiple sclerosis.
newTitle: COVID-19 Infection and Multiple Sclerosis: Study Findings

title: A global polio resurgence and the need to reevaluate the basics - The Hindu
summary:
A Global Polio Resurgence and the Need to Reevaluate Our Approach

Published on: December 26, 2024 10:48 pm IST

Source: Unknown

The article discusses the recent resurgence of polio worldwide, emphasizing the critical need for vigilant vaccination and monitoring. The World Health Organization (WHO) has reported environmental samples of poliovirus detected in several European countries, indicating an ongoing risk.

  • The resurgence includes cases in Pakistan, Cameroon, and Nigeria, with ongoing vaccine-derived poliovirus circulation.
  • WHO emphasizes the importance of vaccination to prevent paralysis and death from poliovirus.
  • A recent debate on the best vaccination approach—the replacement of the oral polio vaccine (OPV) with the inactivated polio vaccine (IPV)—is highlighted.
  • Research suggests respiratory transmission may play a more significant role than previously acknowledged.
“Vaccination of every vulnerable child is essential to ensure that the virus cannot lead to lifelong paralysis or even death.” - Robb Butler, Director, Communicable Diseases, Environment and Health at WHO/Europe.

This global health challenge underscores the need for immediate action in vaccination strategies to safeguard future generations against polio.
newTitle: A Global Polio Resurgence and the Need to Reevaluate Our Approach

title: Which infectious disease is likely to be biggest emerging problem in 2025? - The Indian Express
summary:
Which infectious disease is likely to be biggest emerging problem in 2025?

Publication Date: N/A | Source: Indian Express

The article discusses concerns among public health officials regarding emerging infectious diseases, particularly as COVID-19 recedes. It highlights the potential threat posed by the H5N1 influenza virus and compares it with ongoing threats such as malaria, HIV, and tuberculosis.

  • COVID-19 has raised awareness of the potential for new infectious diseases.
  • Malaria, HIV, and tuberculosis currently kill around 2 million people annually.
  • H5N1 bird flu is spreading among birds and recently infecting cattle in the US.
  • There has been a significant increase in human bird flu cases in 2023.
  • H5N1 has a high mortality rate in humans but does not currently spread between people.
  • A mutation could potentially enable human-to-human transmission of H5N1.
  • Governments are preparing for the possibility of a pandemic by acquiring vaccines and planning responses.
If this strain of bird flu makes that switch and can start transmitting between humans, governments must act quickly to control the spread.

The article concludes that while H5N1 poses a potential threat, existing diseases must also be prioritized in public health initiatives.

title: COVID-19 Infection Not Linked to Changes in MS Symptom Severity - HealthDay
summary:
COVID-19 Infection Not Linked to Changes in MS Symptom Severity

Date: December 26, 2024

Source: HealthDay News

COVID-19 infection is not associated with immediate changes in multiple sclerosis (MS) symptom severity or disability, according to a study published online Dec. 23 in Neurology.

Key Points:

  • The study examined the effects of COVID-19 on MS symptoms using the SymptoMScreen (SMSS).
  • Involved 796 COVID-19 infected participants and 1,336 uninfected participants.
  • Findings showed no significant difference in SMSS scores between the cohorts before or after COVID-19 infection.
"These findings enhance our general understanding of the consequences of infection in people with MS and are reassuring regarding the impact of COVID-19 on the course of MS," the authors write.

Overall, the study provides reassurance that COVID-19 does not worsen MS symptom severity or lead to increased disability in affected individuals.
newTitle: COVID-19 Infection Not Linked to Changes in MS Symptom Severity

title: Atogepant Superior for Efficacy, Functional Measures in Migraine - HealthDay
summary:
Atogepant Superior for Efficacy, Functional Measures in Migraine

Date: December 26, 2024 Source: HealthDay News

The recent study published in Neurology highlights that atogepant 60 mg once daily demonstrates greater efficacy and improved functional measures for adults suffering from migraine compared to placebo.

  • Atogepant significantly reduced the number of migraine days in various studies.
  • Results showed better efficacy in trials ADVANCE, ELEVATE, and PROGRESS.
  • Published results indicate improved quality of life scores for patients using atogepant.
  • The study addresses an important need for effective preventive treatments in migraine management.
"The analyses reported here demonstrate the early efficacy and functional improvements of atogepant and address a key unmet need of providing preventive treatment options with early benefits across the spectrum of migraine disease state severity." - Richard B. Lipton, M.D.

The findings underscore the potential of atogepant as a promising option for migraine sufferers, providing hope for earlier intervention and improved quality of life.
newTitle: Atogepant Shows Superior Efficacy for Migraine Treatment

title: Nile rats and Black Death: Mummy reveals bubonic plague in Egypt 3,290 years ago - The Jerusalem Post
summary:
Nile rats and Black Death: Mummy reveals bubonic plague in Egypt 3,290 years ago

Publication Date: December 26, 2024

Source: The Jerusalem Post

Researchers have uncovered the oldest confirmed case of the plague outside Eurasia in an ancient Egyptian mummy, suggesting that the deadly disease was present in North Africa thousands of years before the Black Death devastated Europe.

  • The mummy revealed traces of Yersinia pestis DNA.
  • Radiocarbon dating places the mummy at approximately 3,290 years ago.
  • Findings support the theory that bubonic plague circulated in North Africa long before the Middle Ages.
  • Symptoms described in ancient texts correlate with plague characteristics.
  • Studies indicate that Yersinia pestis existed globally thousands of years prior to known pandemics.
The bubonic plague was responsible for the deaths of more than 20 million people in Europe alone.

The presence of plague DNA in the mummy indicates that the individual suffered severe symptoms before death, raising questions about whether this was an isolated case or part of a broader epidemic.
newTitle: Oldest Case of Plague Found in Egyptian Mummy

Why non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is now called MASLD - The Indian Express
summary:
Why Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD) is Now Called MASLD

Publication Date: Not specified, Source: Indian Express

This article explains the rebranding of Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD) to Metabolic Dysfunction-Associated Steatotic Liver Disease (MASLD) and highlights its implications for diagnosis and treatment.

  • The term MASLD emphasizes the metabolic dysfunction as the primary cause of liver disease.
  • About 25% of people globally are affected by MASLD, with rates rising significantly in those with type 2 diabetes or obesity.
  • Non-invasive diagnostic methods such as FibroScan and MRI are increasing diagnostic accuracy.
  • Focus on early diagnosis can lead to preventative measures and treatment interventions.
“These interventions can help lower the long-term risks of heart disease, liver failure, and cirrhosis.” - Dr. Sameer Bhati

This change in terminology indicates a shift towards a patient-centered approach in dealing with liver health.
newTitle: Why Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD) is Now Called MASLD

Foods That Keep You Warm in the Winters

As winter approaches, certain foods can help keep your body warm and cozy during the colder months.

  • Spices such as ginger, cinnamon, and chili pepper can boost metabolism and create a warming effect.

title: Whooping Cough Cases Soaring In The US Showing No Signs Of Slowing Down: CDC Warns - TheHealthSite
summary:
Whooping Cough Cases Soaring In The US Showing No Signs Of Slowing Down: CDC Warns

Date: October 2023
Source: The Health Site

Whooping cough, also known as pertussis, is on the rise in the US, with cases reported to be six times higher than last year. This poses a significant threat, particularly to children, and highlights the need for strict health measures.

  • Over 32,000 cases reported this year.
  • Symptoms start mild but can lead to severe coughing fits.
  • Highly contagious; spread through respiratory droplets.
  • Infants under one year are especially vulnerable.
  • Vaccination is the best prevention method.
“Vaccination rates among US children have fallen, increasing vulnerability to outbreaks.”

Health authorities stress the importance of vaccination and seeking prompt treatment to combat this rising threat.
newTitle: Whooping Cough Cases Surge in the US, CDC Issues Warning

summary:
Whooping cough cases in the US hit the highest in a decade

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: Health News

The United States has recorded the highest cases of whooping cough in ten years, prompting health officials to urge vaccination.

  • Cases have surged due to decreased vaccination rates.
  • Public health campaigns are being intensified to encourage immunization.
  • Infants and young children are particularly vulnerable to the disease.
"Vaccination is key to preventing outbreaks and protecting our children," said Dr. Smith, a pediatric infectious disease specialist.

Health officials stress the importance of maintaining high vaccination coverage to prevent future outbreaks.
newTitle: Whooping Cough Cases in the US Reach Decade High

title: Red meat and Diabetes: Should we rethink our plate? - Firstpost
summary:
Red meat and Diabetes: Should we rethink our plate?

Publication Date: December 2024 Source: The Lancet

A groundbreaking study has revealed a concerning connection between red meat consumption and type 2 diabetes, a condition impacting over 462 million people worldwide. This research indicates that both unprocessed and processed red meat intake raises the risk of diabetes significantly across different populations.

  • The study included nearly 2 million participants from 20 countries.
  • A high intake of unprocessed red meat (e.g., beef, lamb, pork) and processed meat (e.g., bacon, salami) linked to increased diabetes incidence.
  • The research observed a weaker link between poultry consumption and diabetes risk.
  • Type 2 diabetes is a severe public health issue with high long-term health implications.
“Red meat has high levels of saturated fat and can disrupt insulin sensitivity.”

Given these findings, a reduction in red meat consumption is advised, particularly in light of current dietary recommendations that suggest limiting daily intake to about 70g.
newTitle: Red Meat's Alarming Link to Type 2 Diabetes: A Study Overview

Expect more pandemics to sweep the globe in the coming decades - Livescience.com
summary:
Expect More Pandemics to Sweep the Globe in the Coming Decades

Publication Date: Unknown Source: Life Science

Pandemics, the global spread of infectious diseases, are expected to increase in frequency. Historical pandemics like the Black Death and Spanish flu highlight the severity that past outbreaks have had on humanity. Recent events, including COVID-19, illustrate that the threat is very much active, and understanding the underlying causes may help avert future outbreaks.

Key Points

  • Increased opportunities for pandemics arise due to the disruption of ecosystems.
  • Climate change and biodiversity loss contribute to the emergence of new diseases.
  • Historical pandemics demonstrate the impact of infectious diseases on global populations.
  • The increase in human-wildlife contact can lead to transferring diseases from wildlife to humans.
  • A planetary health approach is necessary to address the root causes of pandemics.
"Until we effectively address the unsustainable impact we are having on our planet, pandemics will continue to occur."

Overall, proactive measures addressing climate change and protecting biodiversity are crucial to mitigate the risk of future pandemics.
newTitle: Expect More Pandemics to Sweep the Globe in the Coming Decades

title: 6 energy-rich foods to fuel your day - DNA India
summary:
6 Energy-Rich Foods to Fuel Your Day

Date: Dec 26, 2024 Source: DNA

This article discusses six foods that can help maintain energy levels throughout the day, emphasizing their nutritional benefits.

  • Fresh Foods: Essential nutrients support health and energy.
  • Bananas: Great source of natural sugars, potassium, and fiber.
  • Oats: Rich in fiber and complex carbohydrates for slow energy release.
  • Lean Protein: Helps repair muscles and maintain stable blood sugar.
  • Nuts and Seeds: High in fiber, protein, and healthy fats for sustained energy.
  • Water: Vital for nutrient absorption and metabolism.
This information is not DNA's opinion but obtained from media reports.

Incorporating these energy-rich foods into your diet can significantly enhance your daily energy levels and overall well-being.

title: This Infosys-backed Bengaluru Startup is Beating Cancer with Genomics & AI - AIM
summary:
This Infosys-backed Bengaluru Startup is Beating Cancer with Genomics & AI

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: AIM

This article discusses how 4baseCare, a Bengaluru-based oncology precision startup, is transforming cancer treatment in India through genomics and AI. The company recently received significant investment from Infosys Innovation Fund, enabling it to adopt advanced techniques for targeted cancer therapies.

  • 4baseCare was founded in 2018 by Hitesh Goswami and Kshitij Rishi.
  • The startup has received close to $1 million investment from Infosys Innovation Fund.
  • Genome testing for oncology in India has rapidly increased, growing from 5,000-6,000 tests in 2019 to approximately 2 lakh tests now.
  • There are challenges in precision oncology in India, including awareness among oncologists and availability of effective drugs.
  • 4baseCare is leveraging AI for data interpretation and has developed a clinical genomic digital twin model for personalized treatment.
“The whole team, right from the logistics team who picks up a sample, I tell them, ‘Guys, you have no idea which sample you might pick up, and that will change the whole family’s life.'” - Hitesh Goswami

The work being done by 4baseCare reflects a significant step toward personalized cancer treatment in India, despite existing challenges and obstacles.
newTitle: This Infosys-backed Bengaluru Startup is Beating Cancer with Genomics & AI

summary:
Male Infertility: Simple Lifestyle Hacks and Diet Plan to Boost Sperm Health

Publication Date: Dec 26, 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

Nearly 1 in 7 couples struggle with infertility, often due to male factors. This article explores the declining trend of male fertility and offers lifestyle and dietary recommendations to improve sperm health.

  • Male fertility is crucial for conception, with lifestyle, diet, and health impacting sperm quality.
  • Key sperm health indicators include quantity, movement (motility), and structure (morphology).
  • Obesity, smoking, and certain medications can negatively affect sperm quality.
  • Healthy lifestyle changes can significantly enhance fertility outcomes.
“Boosting male fertility requires a holistic approach...” - Dr. Sabia Mangat

Improving male fertility is essential for families trying to conceive, and understanding sperm health can guide men towards better reproductive outcomes.

title: 10 countries with most cancer rates, see where India stands - The Times of India
Cooking oils and cancer: What Indians should be concerned about - The Week
summary:
Cooking oils and cancer: What Indians should be concerned about

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Gut, British Society for Gastroenterology

A recent research published in Gut suggests a connection between certain cooking oils and an increased risk of colon cancer among the young, highlighting a concerning trend in India.

  • The rising incidence of colon and rectal cancer in individuals under 50 is alarming.
  • Processed vegetable oils, such as soybean, sunflower, and palm oils, may contribute to this risk due to their high omega-6 fatty acid content.
  • Refined oils, prevalent in Indian kitchens, often lack essential nutrients and may contain unhealthy trans fats.
  • Deep frying and high-temperature cooking can produce harmful compounds linked to cancer.
  • Dietary factors, lifestyle, and genetics also play a significant role in overall cancer risk.
  • Improving dietary choices, like using unrefined oils and increasing fiber intake, can mitigate risks.
"Small, constant changes could work like magic for our health." - Dr. Mohammed Mithi

In conclusion, while cooking oils may have associated risks, making informed dietary choices can help reduce potential harm.
newTitle: Cooking Oils and Cancer: Important Insights for Indian Cuisine
